greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = prime(A001511(n)), where A001511 is one more than the 2-adic valuation of n.
comment: Originally defined as: a(1) = 2 = prime(1). Then the first occurrence of prime(n) followed by all previous terms. i.e. If the index of first occurrence of prime(n) is k then the next k-1 terms are defined as a(k+r) = a(r), r = 1 to k-1. and a(2k) = prime(n+1) and so on.

Index of the first occurrence of prime(n)= 2^(n-1). Subsidiary sequences: If prime(n) is replaced by f(n) a large number of sequences can be obtained choosing f(n) = composite(n), f(n) = n^2,f(n) = n^r, r =3,4,5,..., f(n) = tau(n), f(n) = sigma(n), f(n) = n!, f(n) = Fibonacci(n), f(n) = T(n), triangular number, f(n) = n-th Bell, etc. each giving a distinct fascinating music.
The lexicographically earliest sequence such that no product of consecutive terms is a perfect square. - _Joshua Zucker_, Apr 30 2011
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16384
results.author: _Amarnath Murthy_, Apr 28 2004
ext: Replaced the name with a formula given by _Omar E. Pol_, which is equivalent to the original definition. - _Antti Karttunen_, Nov 02 2018
